content.description: Start out matched on the big side-pull (rail) and decent feet but in a slightly awkward location, step up and hit the horizontal crack, move your feet up and make a high step into the crack.  Finish up on easy slab moves.
content.location: Starts around the corner from hobbit hole.

content.description:
A fun linkup of 3 boulders.  Start sitting as for Another World, follow edges left, swing feet onto the arete and transition over onto the arete next to When I'm on My Own, then handtraverse the lip to the left to get your feet on the starting hold of Jaws (Texas Chainsaw Massacre), now downclimb Jaws with a reverse mantle (crux), traverse left into the start of Hobbit Hole, and follow the Hobbit Hole crack to the end. 

  Long and pumpy.
content.location: Traverses the whole left side of the Zoo Boulders.

content.description:
A short, crimpy and powerful problem that suffers from a bad case of exfoliation.  In 2004 most of the holds fell off of the face, leaving the problem in its current state.  Its still fun if you have nothing better to do.  Sit start just right of the pocket on the Professor and layback a right hand sidepull with the help of a tiny crimp below the pocket for your left.  Snag the weird crimp in the seam with your left hand and gaston up to a crimp on the face.  Drop into the double gaston and dyno to the lip.   

An incorrect grade and a missing problem in the guidebook have created confusion about this short climb and as a result, it is rarely tried, let alone climbed.  Although the guidebook description of climb broken edges trending right is correct, most people climb its neighbor, the left leaning arete, and mistake it for this problem.  For that problem, please see Mistaken Identity.
content.location: Route on overhanging face just right of The Professor and Hobbit Hole.

content.description: A fun slab climb. Work up the slab, there are a few different ways to go up and all seem around V0. A fun problem for your first time bouldering.
content.location: looking at Edges V2 look at the next boulder to your right. It is a slab rock that often has a good amount of chalk on one of the crimps.

content.description: This problem is listed as a project in the Kemple guide but it has been climbed many times.  Pull on to the face with the help of the left arete, and use tiny holds and delicate feet to dance your way up and slightly left towards the arete and notch.  Highly technical and somewhat scary moves will reward you with a thank-god-jug right before the top.  Although it can appear slightly scruffy, the climbing can be worthwhile.
content.location: In the Zoo, directly behind the Professor.  In fact, if you fall off, you're in danger of hitting the Professor.

content.description: Highball line on the back side of the Smaug Boulder. Sit start at Bilbos Revenge and head straight up the dirty face. All the holds you need are cleaned up good.
content.location: Located on the backside of smaug boulder with Hobbit Hole.  I used the holds on Bilbo's Revenge for a good sit start.

content.description: Traverse in from the left on a little arete, at the overlap grab some jugs, and do a spicy rockover to get to the top.  There's always some large branches in the stream to keep your pads out of the water.  Called Sisyphus because if you don't master the balance, you slowly teeter backwards toward the stream.
content.location: On the same boulder as the Hobbit Hole, but the complete opposite side.  Sometimes it gets grown over, as the crux is directly over the stream.

content.description: This crimpy problem is one of the hardest in the Zoo Area.  It starts on Good Rips, goes left around the corner (under roof), and finishes on Edges.  Sit start on the good jug(s) and immediately toss a heel up with your hands so that you can grab a bad crimp out left with your left hand on the outside of the tunnel.  Don't hit your head as you move your right hand to a crimp just below your left.  Now that you're hanging horizontally, make the crux move up to a good edge on the face.  Control the swing, establish yourself on the face, and finish straight up.
content.location: On the Mushroom Boulder in the Zoo...

content.description:
To the left of Hobbit  Direct is a tree and to the left of the tree is this route. Sit start with a good slopey hold on the lip and a small crimp down and left. Pick some feet and move over the lip using crimps and side-pulls to a long move to  good hold in the horizontal. Then scamper up the easy climbing to the top. 

  I had originally heard this was supposed more in the V4 range but it felt much easier. Let me know what you think... Did I start in the right place?
content.location: To the left of Hobbit  Direct and right of Bilbo's Revenge between two trees.

content.description: This is the tall arete opposite of Hobbit Hole, its not a incredibly tough problem, just a heady problem because its tall. Just keep your head strong and you will be fine. Have fun and trust your feet.
content.location: This is the tall arete opposite of hobbit hole and just left of the chimney created by the Lobster tall bolder and this route. You climb the left arete of that chimney.

content.description:
This climb flies a bit under the radar because it's not in the guidebook, but it's deserving of more attention.  

  Start sitting with two obvious low edges and small feet. Make a hard move to gain a good edge and then continue upward via incuts and sidepulls to a delicate top out. Though the rock is somewhat fragile/hollow feeling, this is a really good climb with great flow to the moves.  

  The landing is a little spooky due to the possibility that you might fall down into a gap between the boulders and end up at the bottom of the start of 'Hobbit Hole'. Given that, it's a good idea to be fairly solid at the grade before climbing this or to have a few pads and spotters.
content.protection: A couple of pads and perhaps a spotter as the possibility of falling into the hole is kind of spooky.
content.location: This climb can be found on top of the boulder that 'Jaws' is on. It climbs an obvious face that is on the same boulder as 'Hobbit Hole'.

content.description: Sit start inside the cave like feature matched on a good hold in a crack. Move leftwards in the crack for a couple of moves, then get high feet and flip the hands to underclings. From here make a hard and long reach up and right to a large sloper shelf. A decent climb with some scrunchy movement and friendly holds.
content.location: From The Lobster Tail head right around the boulder and locate the crack. This problem starts on the right side in a small cave like formation.

content.description:
Sit start on shallow underclings. Pop out left to edge and cross feet. High heel with left hand in super-shallow dish. Super-thin crimp with the right hand. Pull hard and deadpoint to sloping topout holds.    Location of your heel will make this climb V6 for some and V-impossible for others. Accuracy of your heel placement is paramount. 

  As an alternative for 6ft+ climbers, It is possible to make a big move from the right undercling and left flake all the way to the top.
content.location: Just right of Up and on bulging low-ball boulder.

content.description:
A crimpy crux with feet in all the wrong places...Are we in Pawtuckaway or something?... 

  The beta varies, but it's either techy or a big throw at the crux...Then an easy top out....
content.location: On the Mushroom Traverse Boulder...Across from Another World (V1)....

content.description:
This arete is what most people climb when they think they are on When I'm On My Own.  It is missing from the guidebook, but perpetually caked with chalk and was once vandalized by some idiots with a blowtorch.  A foot-long piece of stone dropped off the arete thanks to their carelessness. 

  Sit start the short arete and layback to the top, making use of the crimps on the left face, and also maybe a few high crimps on the right side.  Grab the lip and mantle up.
content.location: Right of The Professor and When I'm On My Own and left of Another World.  The easiest way off the boulder is to scramble down between Jaws and Hobbit Hole.

content.description: This climb starts on the north face of the mushroom boulder and goes clockwise to the topout by the tree on the south side of the boulder.   This problem is a very pumpy and challenging traverse with your hands and right heel up on the top and your left legs getting in the way the whole way around the boulder.
content.location: See above.

content.description:
Sit Start the arete to the left of The Wanderer. The first move is the crux, once you pull over the lip scurry up the arete and slab to the top.  

  The first move is fun but the rest is pretty bland. Not a bad problem to do if you have done all the other easy warm-ups in the area.
content.location: Sit Start the arete to the left of The Wanderer. You start just right of the tunnel that you climb through for Sidewinder.

content.description: Start on the feature that looks like a lobster's tail. Climb up and right on easy ground (jugs and obvious feet). Downclimb/slide other slide on boulder.   This can be a good warm up in winter to get the muscles moving (do it in sneakers).
content.protection: Pad and spotter if you are maxing out at grade.
content.location: Just east of Hobbit Hole at the feature thatlooks like a lobster's tail.

content.description: A fun and easy chimney climb as long as you don't fall and pinball your way down to the ground. Stand start and work your way up the left face towards the top of the "Shillings" arete with good hand and foot holds. Two-thirds of the way up you will transition over to the "Lobster" boulder for the top out.
content.protection: Helmet, no room for pad or spotter.
content.location: The route is in the gap between the Lobster tail and Shillings, across from Hobbit Hole.  The start is on the left once you enter several feet into the gap from the Hobbit Hole side, there are several visibly good handholds.  Get down the back side of the "Lobster Tail" boulder or boulder hop down to the beginning of the Marathon.

content.description: This little route is the left facing arete between "mistaken identity" and "another world" there has been maybe a little more then 3 ascents of it just because it gets over looked.   Start left hand on a sloping pinch and you right hand lower on the arete squeezing a nothing divot. Get a heel hook and magically levitate up to a right hand crimp. struggle to keep the heel and mantle into "another world"    I called it V6+ , but the reality is I don't know...
content.location: the Zoo

content.description: Stand start at the crux of Hobbit Hole with a good fingerlock and get your feet on the wall.  Climb straight up with your choice of a gaston or a sidepull for your left hand and balance up until you can stand in the crack.  Finish up easier terrain.
content.location: Same as Hobbit Hole

content.description:
Two moves.   Sit start, hands up, mantle the buldge and hand foot match to gain the top out. 

  A worthwhile one-move-wonder.
content.location: Mantle probelm just right of Hobbit Hole.

content.description: Crux is the beta, work your own out because everyone's is different for this climb. The climb is amongst the majority of the boulders in Boulder Natural (an area referred to as Gandalf's Lair). It is an obvious up and left slanting lower crack the follows the arete and jugs to the top of the boulder (downclimb route). Lots of climbers find the lower sidepull helpful to use with your left hand to pull the crux move out of the horizontal handcrack.
content.location:
Gandalf's Lair, a.k.a."Boulder Natural" (look for smooth, well-chalked, hand/finger horizontal crack).   

  [Further info on location: It is located at the outskirts of the Zoo, on the largest boulder in the cluster. It is across the corridor from the obvious lobster tail feature. To the right of 'Hobbit Direct', and just right of 'Texas Chainsaw Massacre'. If you can find The Zoo, just walk through the corridor and you should see the chalked up, left-slanting crack.]

content.description: Levitate off bad holds and pop to big crimp on arete, continue up easier ground on arete and downclimb route.   Hard sit start. The start feels like trying to squeeze a hippo between your legs.
content.location: Arete left of Hobbit Hole.

content.description: Sit start the very lowest part of the Mushroom Boulder on the sloping lip. Throw a heel and mantle straight up. Pretty dull, but worth doing once, I suppose.
content.location: This starts on the very lowest part of the Mushroom Boulder (the boulder with Four Hole), in the crux section of the Marathon Traverse. About 5 feet right of Boredom.

content.description:
Start at the base of the juggy flake that also serves as the start for Sidewinder. Continue up the flake and make a big move to the lip.  An intermediate crimp broke off years ago.  Mantle over to finish. 

  No, the tree is not "on".
content.location: On the backside of the Zoo, next to the small tunnel.

content.description:
Climbs a bulge via really bad holds.  Sit/squat start with the two crimps at waist height.  Move up R hand to a sloper/crimp, then match next to it on a sloper.  Work your feet and make a hard move to a crimp (crux).  Stand up on the crimps and topout. 

  Named for a hold that ripped off.
content.location: On the far end of the Zoo away from the trail

content.description: Start standing with hands on nice holds and either make one move then dyno to the top, or work the flake up and left to the top for a more difficult but less dynamic option... the top out is easy making this a good one for firs time boulderers...
content.location: to the right of Power and grace look for a prominent flake...

content.description: Start as for Bilbos Revenge but now that the tree has fallen you can traverse the whole crack to the arete for Hobbit Hole. The tree known as Chris?
content.protection: I guess some pads? You could plug gear.
content.location: Backside Hobbit Hole

content.description: A fun little climb that never gets done. Definitely feels harder than John's Stand Up, but I'm pretty good at crimps so that probably helps. Stand start same as JSU, in the slopiest part of the crack used on Hobbit Hole. Grab a decent LH gas tone and scrunch your feet to the crack. Stand up in the crack, but rather than going straight up to the jug rail, move straight up. Grab a tiny right hand crimp and gun for a good sidepull. Cross over to a mossy edge and grab the juggy arete. Follow the arete to the lip and top out same as Hobbit Hole. It can also be done as a sit start (starting same as Hobbit Hole), which bumps it up to about v6-.
content.location: Start same as John's Stand Up, but move right on bad crimps before gaining the juggy arete.

content.description:
Start on the obvious edges on the right side of the face with a large, good foot and climb straight up on crimps.  Topout over the awesome juggy lip. 

  V4+ as a sit start, and V7 if climbed as the finish of Sidewinder.
content.location: On 10ft High face east of The Professor.

content.description: Are you a fan of head injuries and awkward painful climbing?  Do you enjoy bouldering with a helmet and causing harm to your spotter when you fall?  If so, then this is the climb for you!  On the backside of the Zoo, this sharp arete rises out of a hole and while it doesn't look half bad, it is possibly one of the worst problems in the park.  Start at the base of the arete and climb out of the hole while fighting the barndoor into the other boulder, then as you finally reach the crux, try to avoid cracking your head open or knocking your spotter off of the boulder as you grunt for the lip.
content.protection: Two or three pads, spotter, maybe even a helmet
content.location: On the backside of the Zoo, next to the stream, on the the same boulder as Jaws (Texas Chainsaw Massacre) and The Professor.  From Hobbit Hole you could actually just duck through the cave and come out the back, but it's easier to walk around.

content.description: Inside the chimney to the left of lobster tail is a small cave with a crack running through it, sit start as far back as you can, use the wide crack to a welcoming jug and contortion yourself up the chimney to the top.
content.location: left of lobster tail across from hobbit hole, in the obvious chimney.

content.description: Crouch start same as Barnacle Bill (at the far right side of the crack) and follow Barnacle Bill up to that cool double jug/sidepull. At this point, the rest of the crack is off, as are both of the aretes. Climb straight up the blank face through terrible slopers and tiny knubbins. Top out on jugs.
content.protection: A few pads, spotter not mandatory but encouraged
content.location: It starts same as Barnacle Bill, but at the halfway point, it punches up the slab.

content.description:
Sit start on a crimp rail and fire to the lip and make the casual top out. 

  The name of this route is very appropriate.
content.location: A couple feet right of Good Rips.

content.description: Traverse the crack right, until you reach a tree then topout.
content.location: From boulder natural parking crossover the stream as you enter boulder natural and look to your left and you will see the crack. On the same boulder as hobbit hole

content.description: The painfully obvious crack.  Start with your hands on a shelf with a heel hook by your hands and prepare for judgement day.  Jam, crimp, thrutch, grovel your way across the left slanting crack till you can stand up into underclings and bring your feet up.  Then finish up the far left arete.  The book gives this V3, I think that it is much harder and never gets too much easier.
content.location: To the right and around the corner from lobster tail.

content.description: Sit start on a rounded jug and a sidepull and balance/power your way up and left to slopers for slab topout.   The starting foot will find your shins if you aren't careful.   Hard for the grade, but fun and friction dependent.
content.location: Right of When I'm On My Own.

content.description: The Zoo is a fantastic area to warm up, cool down or j ust hang out in all day. Consisting of a large concentration of moderate boulder problems, making it a great place for beginners as well as the more advanced. The zoo also has some of the most classic problems in all of Pawtuckaway such as Hobbit Hole (V3), Bolt on Top (V1) and The Professor (V5) . Because of this it is a definite must stop for any visiting out of towners.
